course.name: Done is better - Build What Matters

questions.question: A process has 15 steps. How do you find what is essential?
options: Strip to the minimum; find where it breaks; add back only what is necessary
Remove the last 5 steps
Survey users on their favorite steps
Keep all steps but do them faster

questions.question: In this framework, how would you describe "simplify until it breaks" in practice?
options: Remove everything that does not prove the core; the break point shows the minimum
Make the product worse on purpose to test limits
Cut the budget in half and see what survives
Use fewer words in documentation only

questions.question: You have a minimal version. What should you do?
options: Test it; if it achieves the goal, leave elements out; if it breaks, add back only what is necessary
Add more features before testing
Ship it without testing
Archive it

questions.question: Why is adding features before proving the core risky?
options: You invest in complexity before validating that the core works
Features are always good
It pleases more stakeholders
It has no effect on outcomes or learning

questions.question: Equating "simple" with "trivial" can lead to:
options: Dismissing simplification and keeping unnecessary complexity
Faster delivery
Higher quality
Better design

questions.question: What is the purpose of finding where the simplified version breaks?
options: To know the minimum needed; then add back only what is necessary
To prove the idea is bad
To save money
To reduce scope arbitrarily

questions.question: After stripping one element from a plan, how do you decide whether to keep it out?
options: Can you still achieve the goal? If yes, leave it out; if no, add it back
Ask the team to vote
Leave it out to save time
Always add it back
